Comment: My interpretation would be that it's a rebound effect after the hit that recruitment took following the 2nd Iraq war.  It's no surprise that an unpopular war justified by fabricated claims would harm recruitment for years to come. I was saying this before we even went to war and few people were listening to me back then. I was reading the stuff coming out of the [PNAC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_for_the_New_American_Century) (a now-defunct neocon thinktank) so it was no surprise to me when GWB pushed us into that war using 9/11 as an excuse, with no regard to the long-term negative consequences. And the hit to recruitment was one among many of those negative consequences.  I wish people could study the history of this stuff and learn from it. Yeah, people rejected GWB but a lot of people didn't really understand how we got into that mess to begin with, the forces behind it. I wish people had been held accountable and more than that I wish people, including both the Republican base and Republican leadership, learned from their mistakes.  Instead of actually understanding this history, the Republican party has been all "hurr hurr, isolationism!" in a shallow, often kinda knee-jerk way, while Democrats have, bizarrely, welcomed some of the tenets of neocon ideology under their tent, like they've taken the hawkish/interventionist foreign policy and paired it with their social and fiscal stances. And I'm just sitting here frustrated that no one is really having the tough conversations about what went wrong during that period of US history and what we can do to prevent it again.  And it goes back farther too, like a similar thing played out with Vietnam, not exactly the same but there are some parallels.
